that is used to fit a single model to individual time series and then use that
model to extrapolate where that those those data points might be in the future
is a very popular algorithm available in scikit-learn are in other platforms so
it was sort of a superstar before deep learning began to took it place its
place and that's where deep AR camp comes in deep AR and deep AR + which is
an optimized version of deep AR which is included in forecast is a supervised learning algorithm for forecasting
one-dimensional time series using recurrent neural networks or RNs in many
applications you may have a similar time series across a set of cross sectional units these time series groupings might
be different products server loads requests etc so in this case it could be beneficial to train a single model
jointly over all of those time series and deep AR takes this approach when
your data set contains hundreds of feature time series the deep AR plus
recipe which is what we call our algorithms outperforms the standard ARIMA and ets models so you can also use
the trained model for generating forecasts on new time series that are similar to the ones that have been
trained on and that's especially important for say new product introductions ets which stands for
exponential smoothing if it's a single model to each of an individual time
series and then uses that to extrapolate using the exponential window function to
assign exponentially decreasing weights over time instead of constant weights is
applied in a simple moving average technique has a lot of advantages in smoothing the input time series data set
you can apply this to data sets with seasonality or some of their prior assumptions in the data MDM is mixture
data network that is a probabilistic deep neural network algorithm it uses
multiple time series and categorical attributes associated with a particular item to forecast a target valuable this
the MDN algorithm generates output as a mixture of gaussians for all points in
the forecast horizon-- horizon at once mq rnm is unique to amazon that's an
algorithm that we've developed in-house that we use for demand forecasting with other one-dimensional time series
datasets MPTs which is non parametric
time series is a scalable probabilistic baseline forecaster it predicts the
future value distribution of a given time series by sampling from past
observations the predictions are bounded by observed values n pts is especially
useful when the time series is intermittent or sparse or bursty profit
is Facebook's famous time series
predictor yet implements a procedure for forecasting time series based on an
additive model where nonlinear trends are fit with yearly weekly or daily
season and a seasonality plus holidays it works best with time series that have
strong seasonal effects and several seasons of historical data profit is
robust with missing data and shifts in trend and typically handles outliers
well SQ f is an RNN based supervised
learning algorithm for probabilistic forecasting for one dimensional time series the
underlying RNN architecture is similar to deep AR except that it doesn't use
likelihood instead sqf estimates the quantile function directly and uses the
continuous rank probability score as a loss function so s Q after suitable for
time series that did not follow standard parametric likelihood assumptions for example data with heavy tails we also
provide the random forest quantile regressor and a multi-layer perceptron

10 P 50 and P 90 so what do they mean P 10 what that represents is that the true
value in other words the target prediction is expected to be lower than the predicted 10% value of that time so

on other end of that spectrum spectrum we have p90 and that is where the true
value is expected to be lower than the predicted 90% value of the time in the
center we have P 50 which reduces to MAPE or the mean average absolute
